metadata.sermon_title: Zählt nicht uns, sondern eure Tage
metadata.sermon_start_end: Mit dem 90. Psalm verbinde ich einige lebensgeschichtliche Erfahrungen, die ich mitteilen möchte, weil andere vielleicht auch mit dem einen oder anderen Vers dieses Psalms vertraut sind [...] und treib das werk unserer hände voran die gute arbeit der befreiung

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon focuses on Psalm 90, specifically verses 9, 10, 2-6, and 13-17. It identifies a unique tension between 'Feststellung' (observation) and 'Klage' (lament). However, it often drifts into general cultural criticism (SDI, nuclear power) that could be attached to many prophetic texts, losing the absolute specificity of Psalm 90's unique voice on time.
quotes: Der unabkürzbare Weg, auf den dieser Psalm uns lockt, geht von der Feststellung fort zur Klage und von der Klage weiter zur Bitte.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus more sharply on what Psalm 90 says about the 'wrath of God' in relation to time that cannot be found in the prophets or the New Testament.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher demonstrates academic competence by situating the text in the post-exilic period and referencing the Hebrew 'Urtext' regarding the absence of the word 'dying' in verse 12. The connection to Haggai 1:6 provides solid historical grounding.
quotes: Wir können die Zeit, in der dieser Psalm entstanden sein muss, einigermaßen genau bestimmen als die Zeit nach der Rückkehr aus dem babylonischen Exil.
Aber das Wort »sterben« steht im Urtext nicht, dort heißt es: »Lehre uns unsere Tage zählen...«
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Avoid using exegesis merely to validate modern political stances; ensure the 'strangeness' of the ancient context is maintained.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: While concrete (referencing SDI, the census, Fritz Schumacher), the application often feels like a pre-packaged political agenda (anti-technology, anti-capitalist) rather than an application emerging strictly from the text's theological core. It risks becoming a 'speech about refugees/politics' which Dekker warns against.
quotes: Sein aktueller Anlass war die Volkszählung, die von vielen Menschen als ein Ausdruck des Allmachtswahns des Staates verstanden wurde.
Ich denke an Fritz Schumacher... »Small is beautiful«
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the political critique more directly to the 'wrath of God' as a theological category rather than a sociological one.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a structure of personal anecdote, then conservative vs. liberating exegesis, then contemporary context. While not strictly separated, the 'four levels' mentioned by the preacher create a somewhat mechanical movement from text to world.
quotes: Jeder produktive Umgang mit der Bibel setzt vier verschiedene Ebenen zueinander in Beziehung...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the text's imagery (grass, flood, watch in the night) to interpret the modern world directly rather than explaining the 'method' of application.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The category of 'misery' is strongly present, redefined as 'Allmachtswahn' (delusion of omnipotence). Redemption is framed as 'Umkehr' (turning) and God's 'Solidarität'. Gratitude is expressed in the final prayer as the 'work of liberation'.
quotes: Fürwahr, mit uns ist es aus durch deinen Zorn...
Sättige uns am Morgen mit deiner Solidarität...
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure 'redemption' is clearly anchored in Christ's work (outside the self) rather than just human 'Umkehr' (turning).

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon addresses 'being lost in time' through the destruction of the environment and the poor. It takes the 'wrath of God' seriously as a consequence of human action. However, it leans heavily on the collective/temporal loss and ignores the individual/eternal dimension Luther emphasized.
quotes: ...dass wer Gift in die Flüsse leitet, seine Kinder zum Verdursten verurteilt.
Heute weiß ich genauer, dass es zur Grundverfassung dieses verletzlichen Lebens gehört, dass wer Wind sät, Sturm ernten wird
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Integrate the individual's responsibility before God (coram Deo) beyond collective socio-economic guilt.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is the weakest point according to Dekker's criteria. Christ is almost entirely absent from the main body of the sermon. While the 'telos' is God's grace/solidarity, the specific person and work of Jesus Christ (the 'One Lord') is not the focal point.
quotes: Gott will uns an der guten Macht des Lebens beteiligen.
Gott, das Geheimnis des Lebens, wird uns tragen...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'turning of God' (v. 13) to the incarnation and the cross, as Dekker requires Christ to be the telos.

8_depth_and_length.findings: With approximately 2450 words, the sermon meets the requirement for 'breadth' and 'depth'. It allows for a slow development of thought and multiple layers of meaning.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Maintain this length but increase the density of the 'One Lord' (Thesis 7) within that space.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a substantial engagement with Psalm 90 but falls short of Dekker's 'One Lord' criterion. It excels in identifying 'misery' within the zeitgeist (Allmachtswahn) and utilizes solid exegesis. However, it borders on a political speech, and the absence of a clear Christological telos makes it more of a 'theological-cultural reflection' than a sermon in the strict Barthian/Dekkerian sense.
strengths: Adequate length allowing for genuine theological depth.
Strong identification of the 'misery' of the modern hearer (technological hubris).
Traceable exegesis regarding the Hebrew text and historical context.
weaknesses: Significant lack of explicit Christology; Christ is not the telos.
Application is overly focused on collective/political loss, neglecting individual spiritual standing.
The 'four-level' method makes the interwovenness of text and life feel somewhat clinical.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a strong religious speech with high exegetical quality, but it is an incomplete sermon because it fails to center on the 'One Lord' (Christ) as the specific goal of the proclamation.
